subjects.name: Chemistry
subjects.description: The scientific study of the properties and behavior of matter.

modules.title: Organic Chemistry
modules.description: The study of carbon-containing compounds, their structure, reactions, and synthesis.

modules.title: Inorganic Chemistry
modules.description: The study of inorganic compounds, metals, minerals, and organometallics.

modules.title: Analytical Chemistry
modules.description: The science of obtaining, processing, and communicating information about the composition and structure of matter.

topics.title: Introduction to Analytical Chemistry
topics.description: The foundational overview of the scope, methods, and systematic process of analytical chemistry.
outcomes: Define analytical chemistry and distinguish between qualitative and quantitative analysis.
Classify analytical methods into gravimetric, volumetric, electroanalytical, and spectroscopic categories.
Outline the steps in a typical quantitative analysis.

sections.title: 1A: The Role of Analytical Chemistry
sections.content:
The Nature of Analytical Chemistry

Analytical chemistry is a measurement science consisting of a set of powerful ideas and methods that are useful in all fields of science, engineering, and medicine.

sections.title: 1B: Classifying Quantitative Analytical Methods
sections.content:
Classification of Methods

Classical Methods: Wet chemical methods such as precipitation and extraction.
Instrumental Methods: Measurements of physical properties like conductivity, electrode potential, or light absorption.

sections.title: 1C: Stepping Through a Typical Quantitative Analysis
sections.content:
The Analytical Process

The flow of analysis: 1. Select Method 2. Acquire Sample 3. Process Sample 4. Eliminate Interferences 5. Calibrate & Measure 6. Calculate Results 7. Evaluate Reliability.

topics.title: Errors in Chemical Analysis
topics.description: An introduction to the statistical treatment of data, ensuring reliability in analytical results.
outcomes: Distinguish between systematic (determinate) and random (indeterminate) errors.
Calculate the mean, standard deviation, and coefficient of variation for a data set.
Differentiate between accuracy (closeness to true value) and precision (reproducibility).

sections.title: 5A: Mean and Median
sections.content:
Mean and Median

Definition and calculation of central tendency measures.

sections.title: 5B: Precision and Accuracy
sections.content:
Precision and Accuracy

Exploring the difference between reproducibility and truth in measurements.

sections.title: 5C: Types of Errors in Experimental Data
sections.content:
Types of Errors

Systematic vs. Random errors and their sources.

topics.title: Gravimetric Methods of Analysis
topics.description: Quantitative methods based on determining the mass of a pure compound to which the analyte is chemically related.
outcomes: Explain the mechanism of precipitate formation: nucleation and particle growth.
Perform stoichiometric calculations to determine analyte concentration from precipitate mass.
Differentiate between colloidal and crystalline precipitates.
Understand the principles of volatilization gravimetry.

sections.title: 12A: Precipitation Gravimetry
sections.content:
Precipitation Gravimetry

The analyte is separated from a solution of the sample as a precipitate and converted to a compound of known composition that can be weighed.

sections.title: 12B: Calculation of Results from Gravimetric Data
sections.content:
Calculation of Results

Using stoichiometric ratios and gravimetric factors to find the mass of the analyte.

sections.title: 12C: Properties of Precipitates and Precipitating Agents
sections.content:
Properties of Precipitates

Discussion on particle size, filterability, and purity (coprecipitation).

sections.title: 12D: Volatilization Gravimetry
sections.content:
Volatilization Gravimetry

The analyte is separated from other constituents of the sample by conversion to a gas of known chemical composition.

topics.title: Titrimetric Methods (Volumetry)
topics.description: Methods in which the volume of a reagent of known concentration is used to determine the analyte.
outcomes: Define standard solution, equivalence point, and end point.
Classify titrations into Neutralization, Precipitation, Complexometric, and Redox types.
Construct and interpret titration curves (pH, pAg, pM, E) for all method types.
Perform stoichiometric calculations for each titration category.

sections.title: Introduction & Fundamentals
sections.content:
1. Core Definition

Titrimetry is a group of quantitative analytical methods determining analyte amount by measuring the quantity of a reagent.

2. Vocabulary

  • Titrant: Reagent of known concentration.
  • Analyte: Solution of unknown concentration.
  • Equivalence Point: Theoretical point where moles of titrant = moles of analyte.
  • End Point: Experimental point of physical change.

quiz.question: Which term describes the theoretical point where moles of titrant equals moles of analyte?
What is the primary difference between Volumetric and Gravimetric Titrimetry?
options: One measures acid, the other measures base
One uses a burette (Volume), the other uses a balance (Mass)
One uses electricity, the other uses liquid
quiz.answer: One uses a burette (Volume), the other uses a balance (Mass)

quiz.question: Which of the following is a requirement for a Primary Standard?
options: It must be highly purified and stable in air
It must have a low molar mass
quiz.answer: It must be highly purified and stable in air

sections.title: Standard Solutions
sections.content:
Primary Standards

A highly purified compound that serves as the reference material.

Standardization

The process of determining the concentration of a solution by titrating it against a primary standard.

sections.title: Neutralization Titrations (Theory)
sections.content:
Acid-Base Reactions

Titrations relying on the reaction between hydronium ions (H3O+) and hydroxide ions (OH-).

sections.title: Neutralization: Calculations & Curves
sections.content:
Calculating pH Profiles

Methodology for calculating pH at the Initial, Pre-Equivalence, Equivalence, and Post-Equivalence stages.

sections.title: Precipitation Titrations (Theory)
sections.content:
Formation of Solids

Based on reactions that yield ionic compounds of limited solubility (e.g., AgCl).

sections.title: Precipitation: Calculations & Curves
sections.content:
Calculating p-Functions

Using solubility products (Ksp) to calculate pAg or pCl concentrations.

sections.title: Complexometric Titrations (Theory)
sections.content:
Metal-Ligand Complexation

Based on the formation of a complex. The most famous titrant is EDTA.

sections.title: Complexometric: Calculations & Curves
sections.content:
Calculating pM

Using Formation Constants (Kf) to determine free metal ion concentration.

sections.title: Redox Titrations (Theory)
sections.content:
Electron Transfer

Based on the transfer of electrons between the analyte and titrant.

sections.title: Redox: Calculations & Curves
sections.content:
Calculating Potentials

Using the Nernst Equation to calculate the system potential (E_cell).

topics.title: Introduction to Electrochemistry
topics.description: The study of oxidation-reduction reactions and their application in analytical techniques.
outcomes: Describe the operation of an electrochemical cell.
Calculate electrode potentials using the Nernst Equation.
Differentiate between galvanic and electrolytic cells.

sections.title: 18A: Characterizing Oxidation-Reduction Reactions
sections.content:
Redox Reactions

Review of oxidation, reduction, oxidizing agents, and reducing agents.

sections.title: 18B: Electrochemical Cells
sections.content:
Electrochemical Cells

Structure of Galvanic and Electrolytic cells, including the salt bridge.

sections.title: 18C: Electrode Potentials
sections.content:
Electrode Potentials

Understanding the standard hydrogen electrode (SHE) and standard electrode potentials.

topics.title: Introduction to Spectrochemical Methods
topics.description: Analysis based on the interaction of electromagnetic radiation with matter.
outcomes: Describe the wave and particle properties of electromagnetic radiation.
Explain the phenomena of absorption, emission, and scattering.
Understand the relationship between frequency, wavelength, and energy.

sections.title: 24A: Properties of Electromagnetic Radiation
sections.content:
Properties of Light

Wavelength, frequency, velocity, and the electromagnetic spectrum.

sections.title: 24B: Interaction of Radiation with Matter
sections.content:
Interaction with Matter

How photons interact with atoms and molecules to cause transitions.

sections.title: 24C: Absorption of Radiation
sections.content:
Absorption

The principle of ground state to excited state transitions.

modules.description: The study of inference with purely formal content, based on 'Logic in Computer Science' by Huth and Ryan. Covers Propositional, Predicate, and Modal Logic.

topics.title: Propositional Logic
topics.description: The calculus of reasoning about propositions, analyzing argument structure over content.
outcomes: Distinguish between argument structure and content.
Translate natural language into atomic symbols ($p, q$).
Apply the complete set of Natural Deduction rules.
Construct rigorous proofs using sub-proofs (boxes).

sections.title: 1.0: The Aim of Logic
sections.content:
Why do we need Logic?

As computer scientists, our job is to model the real world. But the real world is messy! We need a way to reason about situations formally so that our arguments - and our code - are airtight.

1. The Intuition Trap (The Toaster Problem)

In everyday life, we use intuition to judge arguments. Consider this argument in plain English:

The Argument (English):
1. If an object is a computer, then it needs electricity.
2. My toaster needs electricity.
3. Therefore, my toaster is a computer.

Wait, that's obviously wrong. But why? To find the bug, we need to translate this from English into Logic.

2. Step 1: Defining the Atoms

First, we identify the independent declarative sentences (facts) and assign them a variable, usually starting with $p$ and $q$. These are called Atoms.

SymbolEnglish Meaning
$p$The object is a computer
$q$The object needs electricity

3. Step 2: The Formal Structure

Now, we replace the English sentences with our symbols to see the skeleton of the argument:

Rule: $p \rightarrow q$ (If Computer, then Electricity)
Fact: $q$ (Has Electricity)
Conclusion: $p$ (Must be Computer)

This is a logical bug! This specific pattern is called Affirming the Consequent. Just because you have the result ($q$), doesn't mean you have the specific cause ($p$).

Coming Up:
We can spot the bug, but how do we speak the language? In the next lesson, we define exactly what sentences are allowed.

sections.title: 1.1: Declarative Sentences & Syntax
sections.content:
Talking to Machines

Natural language is messy. Computers require absolute precision. We use Propositional Logic, built on sentences that have exactly one meaning.

1. The Declarative Filter

Definition: Declarative Sentence
A sentence is declarative if and only if it can, in principle, be declared True or False.

Test Yourself:

  1. The sum of 3 and 5 is 8. (YES: True)
  2. Could you pass the salt? (NO: Request)
  3. Ready, steady, go! (NO: Command)

2. The Logic Hierarchy (BODMAS)

To avoid ambiguity in expressions like $\neg p \wedge q \rightarrow r$, we follow binding rules:

  1. $\neg$ (Tightest): Binds to neighbor.
  2. $\wedge, \vee$: Bind next.
  3. $\rightarrow$ (Loosest): Binds last.
Coming Up:
Now that we have the syntax, how do we use it? We need a framework to manipulate these symbols.

sections.title: 1.2: Natural Deduction Framework
sections.content:
The Calculus of Reasoning

Instead of massive Truth Tables, we use Natural Deduction to derive answers step-by-step.

The Sequent

$\phi_1, \phi_2 \vdash \psi$
  • $\vdash$ (Turnstile): "Given the inputs on the left, I can prove the output on the right."
  • Introduction Rules: Building complex sentences.
  • Elimination Rules: Breaking sentences down.
Coming Up:
Let's start with the easiest tool in the box: The Stapler (Conjunction).

sections.title: 1.3: Conjunction Rules (∧)
sections.content:
The Stapler

Conjunction is the most intuitive logical operator. It simply means "Both are true".

1. And-Introduction ($\wedge I$)

The Formula: $$\frac{\phi \quad \psi}{\phi \wedge \psi}$$

Analogy (The Stapler): Imagine you have two loose pages ($p$ and $q$). This rule allows you to staple them together into a single packet ($p \wedge q$).

Example 1 (Abstract): $p, q \vdash p \wedge q$

1$p$premise
2$q$premise
3$p \wedge q$$\wedge I$ 1,2

2. And-Elimination ($\wedge E$)

The Formula: $$\frac{\phi \wedge \psi}{\phi} \quad \text{and} \quad \frac{\phi \wedge \psi}{\psi}$$

Analogy (The Remover): If you have a stapled packet, you can rip the pages apart to use just one of them. You can discard the other if you don't need it.

Example 2 (Extraction): $p \wedge q, r \vdash q \wedge r$

1$p \wedge q$premise
2$r$premise
3$q$$\wedge E_2$ 1
4$q \wedge r$$\wedge I$ 3,2
Coming Up:
Sometimes we have negatives. What happens if we have two negatives? Next, we look at Double Negation.

sections.title: 1.4: Double Negation Rules (¬¬)
sections.content:
The Toggle Switch

In classical logic, negating a negation brings you back to the start.

1. Double Negation Introduction ($ eg eg I$)

The Formula: $$ rac{\phi}{ eg eg \phi}$$

Analogy: If a light is ON ($p$), it is true that "It is not the case that the light is NOT on" ($ eg eg p$). You can add the double negative freely.

2. Double Negation Elimination ($ eg eg E$)

The Formula: $$ rac{ eg eg \phi}{\phi}$$

Analogy: If I say "I don't disagree", that means "I agree". Two negatives cancel out.

Example 1: $p, eg eg (p ightarrow q) \vdash q$

1$p$premise
2$ eg eg (p ightarrow q)$premise
3$p ightarrow q$$ eg eg E$ 2
4$q$$ ightarrow E$ 3,1
Coming Up:
We just used an arrow ($ ightarrow$) in the example above. How does that actually work? Next is the most famous rule in logic.

sections.title: 1.5: Implication Elimination (→E)
sections.content:
Modus Ponens (The Trigger)

This is the engine of logic. It allows us to apply rules to facts.

The Formula

$$\frac{\phi \rightarrow \psi \quad \phi}{\psi}$$

Definition: If you have a Rule ($p \rightarrow q$) and you have the Trigger ($p$), you are compelled to accept the Result ($q$).

The Analogy: Function Calls

Think of $p \rightarrow q$ as a function definition in code:

def calculate_tax(income):  return tax

The function sits there doing nothing until you Call it with an input (`income`). Once you have the input ($p$), the function runs and gives you the output ($q$).

Example 1: The Chain

Sequent: $p, p \rightarrow q, q \rightarrow r \vdash r$

1$p$premise
2$p \rightarrow q$premise
3$q \rightarrow r$premise
4$q$$\rightarrow E$ 2,1 (Fire first rule)
5$r$$\rightarrow E$ 3,4 (Fire second rule)
Coming Up:
We know how to use rules. But how do we make them? To prove "If P then Q", we need to enter a hypothetical world. Before we do that, we need to learn about Scope.

sections.title: 1.6: Structural Rule: Copy
sections.content:
Scope Management

Before we learn how to open sub-proofs (boxes), we must learn how to move data into them.

The Rule

Definition: Any line appearing in a main proof can be repeated (copied) inside a sub-proof box.

Analogy: Global Variables
In programming, if you declare a variable at the top of your file (Global Scope), you can use it inside any function (Local Scope).

The Copy Rule is just pulling a global variable into your local function so you can use it.

1$p$Global Variable
2...Local Scope Start
3$p$Copy 1
Coming Up:
Now that we know how to handle scope, we are ready to open our first Box. Next: Creating Implications.

sections.title: 1.7: Implication Introduction (→I)
sections.content:
The Virtual Machine (Boxes)

This is the first rule that requires a Sub-proof.

The Concept

To prove $p \rightarrow q$, we don't need $p$ to be true in reality. We just need to show that IF $p$ were true, $q$ would follow.

Analogy: The Sandbox
Imagine you want to test if a virus code ($p$) crashes a computer ($q$). You don't run it on your main PC! You open a Virtual Machine (a Box).
1. You safely assume the virus runs (Assumption).
2. You watch what happens.
3. If it crashes ($q$), you close the VM and report: "If Virus, Then Crash".

Example 1: Simple Derivation

Sequent: $p \rightarrow q \vdash p \rightarrow q$ (Trivial, but shows structure)

1$p \rightarrow q$premise
2$p$assumption (Open VM)
3$q$$\rightarrow E$ 1,2 (Use Global fact)
4$p \rightarrow q$$\rightarrow I$ 2-3 (Close VM)
Coming Up:
We have mastered AND and IMPLIES. Now, let's look at the tricky one: OR.

sections.title: 1.8: Disjunction Introduction (∨I)
sections.content:
The Safe Bet

Making an OR statement is surprisingly easy.

The Formula

$$\frac{\phi}{\phi \vee \psi} \quad (\vee I_1) \quad \quad \frac{\psi}{\phi \vee \psi} \quad (\vee I_2)$$

Analogy: The Insurance
If you hold a winning lottery ticket ($p$), you can confidently say "I have a winning ticket OR I am a Martian" ($p \vee q$).
It doesn't matter that the second part is nonsense. As long as one part is true, the whole statement is true.

Example 1: Padding Truth

Sequent: $p \vdash (p \vee q) \wedge (p \vee r)$

1$p$premise
2$p \vee q$$\vee I_1$ 1
3$p \vee r$$\vee I_1$ 1
4$(p \vee q) \wedge (p \vee r)$$\wedge I$ 2,3
Coming Up:
Creating an OR is easy. Using one is hard. If I tell you "A or B is true", how do you prove C? You need Case Analysis.

sections.title: 1.9: Disjunction Elimination (∨E)
sections.content:
Case Analysis (The Switch Statement)

This is widely considered the hardest rule for beginners because it requires two sub-proof boxes.

The Formula

If you have $\phi \vee \psi$, you must show that $\chi$ follows from $\phi$, AND that $\chi$ follows from $\psi$.

The Analogy: The Switch Statement

In programming, if a variable `user_input` can be 'A' or 'B', you must write code to handle both.

switch(user_input):  case 'A': return true;  case 'B': return true;

If both cases return True, then the function is valid regardless of the input.

Example 1: Commutativity

Sequent: $p \vee q \vdash q \vee p$

1$p \vee q$premise
2$p$assumption (Case 1)
3$q \vee p$$\vee I_2$ 2
4$q$assumption (Case 2)
5$q \vee p$$\vee I_1$ 4
6$q \vee p$$\vee E$ 1, 2-3, 4-5
Coming Up:
We have covered all standard operators. Now we enter the "Upside Down". How do we prove things by showing they are impossible? Next: Contradiction.

sections.title: 1.10: Contradiction Rules (⊥)
sections.content:
The Crash Report

In logic, a contradiction ($ ot$, called 'Bottom') represents a state that is impossible, like "It is raining AND It is not raining".

1. Contradiction Introduction ($ ot I$)

Definition: If you have $p$ and $ eg p$, the universe crashes.

Example: $p, eg p \vdash ot$

2. Contradiction Elimination ($ ot E$)

Definition: If you have reached $ ot$, you can derive ANYTHING. This is called Ex Falso Quodlibet (From falsehood, anything follows).

Analogy: If $1 = 0$, then I am the Pope. Once logic is broken, all rules disappear.

Example: $p, eg p \vdash ext{UnicornsExist}$

1$p$premise
2$ eg p$premise
3$ ot$$ eg E$ 1,2
4UnicornsExist$ ot E$ 3
Coming Up:
Why is Contradiction useful? It's the core of our final and most powerful rule: Proof by Contradiction.

sections.title: 1.11: Negation Introduction (¬I)
sections.content:
Proof by Contradiction

This is the Sherlock Holmes rule: "When you have eliminated the impossible, whatever remains, however improbable, must be the truth."

The Strategy

To prove $ eg p$ (that $p$ is false):

  1. Open a box and Assume $p$ is True (Play devil's advocate).
  2. Reason forward until you hit a Contradiction ($ ot$).
  3. Since assuming $p$ broke the universe, $p$ must be false.
  4. Close the box and conclude $ eg p$.

Example 1: The Crash Test

Sequent: $p ightarrow q, p ightarrow eg q \vdash eg p$

1$p ightarrow q$premise
2$p ightarrow eg q$premise
3$p$assumption (Let's pretend...)
4$q$$ ightarrow E$ 1,3
5$ eg q$$ ightarrow E$ 2,3
6$ ot$$ eg E$ 4,5 (Crash!)
7$ eg p$$ eg I$ 3-6

topics.title: Predicate Logic
topics.description: An extension of propositional logic that uses quantifiers and predicates to express properties of objects.
outcomes: Translate natural language sentences into predicate logic using quantifiers.
Distinguish between Free and Bound variables.
Apply Natural Deduction rules for Universal ($\forall$) and Existential ($\exists$) quantifiers.
Understand the difference between Syntax (formulas) and Semantics (models).

sections.title: 2.1: The Need for a Richer Language
sections.content:
Limitations of Propositions

Propositional logic cannot express relationships between objects. Predicate logic introduces:

  • Predicates: $S(x)$ for 'x is a student'.
  • Variables: Placeholders like $x, y$.
  • Quantifiers: $\forall$ (For all) and $\exists$ (There exists).

sections.title: 2.2: Predicate Logic as a Formal Language
sections.content:
Syntax

Terms represent objects. Formulas represent truth values. A variable is free if it is not inside the scope of a quantifier; otherwise, it is bound.

sections.title: 2.3: Proof Theory of Predicate Logic
sections.content:
Quantifier Rules

New natural deduction rules include:

  • $\forall x$ elimination: If $\forall x \phi$, then $\phi[t/x]$ (substituting any term $t$).
  • $\exists x$ introduction: If $\phi[t/x]$, then $\exists x \phi$.

sections.title: 2.4: Semantics of Predicate Logic
sections.content:
Models

To evaluate a predicate formula, we need a Model which defines the domain of objects and the specific meaning of predicates (e.g., defining exactly who 'Students' are in a specific context).

quiz.question: Which quantifier translates to 'For all' or 'Every'?
In the formula $\forall x (P(x) \rightarrow Q(y))$, which variable is Free?

topics.title: Modal Logic
topics.description: Logic engineering for reasoning about necessity, time, and knowledge using possible worlds semantics.
outcomes: Differentiate between various modes of truth (necessity, belief, knowledge).
Evaluate formulas using Kripke Models (Worlds, Accessibility Relation).
Understand Correspondence Theory: how axioms relate to properties of the accessibility relation (Reflexive, Transitive, Euclidean).
Apply the logic KT45 (S5) to reasoning about knowledge.

sections.title: 5.1: Modes of Truth
sections.content:
Beyond True and False

Modal logic adds unary connectives to express 'modes' of truth, such as:

  • Necessity: It is necessarily true that $\phi$.
  • Time: It will always be true that $\phi$.
  • Knowledge: Agent Q knows that $\phi$.

sections.title: 5.2: Basic Modal Logic (Syntax & Semantics)
sections.content:
Kripke Models

A model consists of a set of Worlds (W) and an Accessibility Relation (R) between them.

  • $\Box \phi$ (Box): True if $\phi$ is true in all accessible worlds.
  • $\Diamond \phi$ (Diamond): True if $\phi$ is true in at least one accessible world.

sections.title: 5.3: Logic Engineering & Correspondence
sections.content:
Designing Logic

We can 'engineer' a logic by choosing axioms that force the accessibility relation to have specific properties:

  • Axiom T ($\Box \phi \rightarrow \phi$): Requires R to be Reflexive. (Used for Knowledge).
  • Axiom 4 ($\Box \phi \rightarrow \Box \Box \phi$): Requires R to be Transitive. (Positive Introspection).
  • Axiom 5 ($\Diamond \phi \rightarrow \Box \Diamond \phi$): Requires R to be Euclidean. (Negative Introspection).

sections.title: 5.5: Reasoning about Knowledge (KT45)
sections.content:
The Logic of Knowledge

The logic KT45 (also called S5) models the knowledge of idealised agents. It assumes agents are truthful (T), know what they know (4), and know what they do not know (5).

quiz.question: In a Kripke model, when is $\Box \phi$ true at world w?
options: If $\phi$ is true in at least one world accessible from w.
If $\phi$ is true in ALL worlds accessible from w.
If $\phi$ is false in all worlds.
quiz.answer: If $\phi$ is true in ALL worlds accessible from w.

quiz.question: Which property of the accessibility relation R corresponds to the axiom $\Box \phi \rightarrow \phi$ (Truth)?
In the logic of knowledge (KT45), what does the axiom '5' (Negative Introspection) state?
options: If I know P, then P is true.
If I know P, I know that I know P.
If I don't know P, I know that I don't know P.
quiz.answer: If I don't know P, I know that I don't know P.
